p: Moreover, studies note that crop failure and related upstream variables like rainfall deficit can predict migration that may drive instability if migrants are competing with established populations for jobs and resources ( Gray and Mueller 2012; Hunter et al. 2013). However, current evidence does not suggest that climate-driven migrants increase the risk of conflict in their destinations ( Cattaneo and Bosetti 2017). Nevertheless, even if climate-driven migrant flows do not trigger wide-scale instability, these migrants are likely to experience a variety of adverse social and health outcomes ( McMichael et al. 2012). The experience of these outcomes, including social marginalization, joblessness, and high rates of infectious disease and malnutrition, are likely to stretch health system capacity, potentially resulting in unrest in cases where health institutions fail to satisfactorily address population needs.
